node.contents: Please state what you will do with the byte array. If you're sending it to a file or another application via sockets or IPC, keeping a reference that only makes sense in the application itself, in that running process, is useless.

node.contents: In that case you are sunk because Java will not run with 1 MB of memory, not even a program which doesn't do anything. It appears your requirement were written for another language because they don't make sense unless you have an embedded device (which wont support Java). BTW your Block object takes 16 bytes and your `byte[]` take another 16 bytes over and above the `128` bytes you allocated. BTW Java doesn't have pointers by design.

astNode.text: In that case you are sunk because Java will not run with 1 MB of memory, not even a program which doesn't do anything. It appears your requirement were written for another language because they don't make sense unless you have an embedded device (which wont support Java). BTW your Block object takes 16 bytes and your `byte[]` take another 16 bytes over and above the `128` bytes you allocated. BTW Java doesn't have pointers by design.

node.contents: Even if you has a C program, to address 1 MB you need 20-bit addresses which requires more than 2 bytes, unless you have an 8086 which was popular 30 years ago, and it could address up to 1 MB of memory using a combination of 16-bit address. Is the puzzle 30 years old?

astNode.text: Even if you has a C program, to address 1 MB you need 20-bit addresses which requires more than 2 bytes, unless you have an 8086 which was popular 30 years ago, and it could address up to 1 MB of memory using a combination of 16-bit address. Is the puzzle 30 years old?

node.contents: Basically, you cannot do this at all in pure Java.

astNode.text: Basically, you cannot do this at all in pure Java.

node.contents: And the non-pure Java ways to do this (using JNI or the Unsafe class) will give you a value that you cannot safely turn back into a Java reference.

astNode.text: And the non-pure Java ways to do this (using JNI or the Unsafe class) will give you a value that you cannot safely turn back into a Java reference.

node.contents: The reason is that when the GC runs, it will typically move reachable objects to new locations. Now if you have a reference to an object in a proper reference-typed field, variable or array slot, the GC will find that reference copy and update it to point to the object's new location. But if the reference has been turned into bytes or something else, then the GC won't know that the bytes are actually a representation of a reference, and won't update it. So your reference-represented-as-bytes will now point to the wrong place. If you turn it back into a reference and attempt to use it, mayhem is likely to ensue.

astNode.text: The reason is that when the GC runs, it will typically move reachable objects to new locations. Now if you have a reference to an object in a proper reference-typed field, variable or array slot, the GC will find that reference copy and update it to point to the object's new location. But if the reference has been turned into bytes or something else, then the GC won't know that the bytes are actually a representation of a reference, and won't update it. So your reference-represented-as-bytes will now point to the wrong place. If you turn it back into a reference and attempt to use it, mayhem is likely to ensue.

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: You need to find a different way to denote these Block references. If you are not willing to serialize the Block objects themselves, the obvious options are indexes or Map keys of some kind. In all cases, your data structure will need to hold the real references in objects / arrays that are reachable by the garbage collector.

astNode.text: You need to find a different way to denote these Block references. If you are not willing to serialize the Block objects themselves, the obvious options are indexes or Map keys of some kind. In all cases, your data structure will need to hold the real references in objects / arrays that are reachable by the garbage collector.

node.contents: +1 `You can obtain where an object was in memory` ummm, how can this be done in Java?

astNode.text: +1 `You can obtain where an object was in memory` ummm, how can this be done in Java?

node.contents: You can use JNI or `sun.misc.Unsafe` to obtain the reference as in `int` or `long` value to see its location but this only tells you where it was because by the time you have the number it could have changed. For 64-bit JVMs it doesn't really tell you the absolute location because it uses 32-bit references for up to 32 GB of memory and can use a translated such as `reference * 8 + offset` to get the actual location in memory.

astNode.text: You can use JNI or `sun.misc.Unsafe` to obtain the reference as in `int` or `long` value to see its location but this only tells you where it was because by the time you have the number it could have changed. For 64-bit JVMs it doesn't really tell you the absolute location because it uses 32-bit references for up to 32 GB of memory and can use a translated such as `reference * 8 + offset` to get the actual location in memory.

node.contents: You can do this by storing a Block index.

astNode.text: You can do this by storing a Block index.

node.contents: e.g

astNode.text: e.g

elements.contents: // list of blocks so you can lookup any block using a 16-bit index. List<Block> blocks = new ArrayList<Block>(); int indexInBlocksToNext = ... data[126] = (byte) (indexInBlocksToNext >> 8); data[127] = (byte) indexInBlocksToNext;

node.contents: All 32-bit systems use 32-bit pointers or references. You can't places an reference in Java because there is no global way of referring to an object via a number. You can obtain where an object was in memory, but this location can change at any time.

astNode.text: All 32-bit systems use 32-bit pointers or references. You can't places an reference in Java because there is no global way of referring to an object via a number. You can obtain where an object was in memory, but this location can change at any time.

node.contents:
1. first Serialize Block Class.
  2. then using something like following to convert block object to byte array.

node.contents: ` public byte[] toByteArray(Object obj) {//

astNode.text: ` public byte[] toByteArray(Object obj) {//

elements.contents: byte[] bytes = null; ByteArrayOutputStream bos = new ByteArrayOutputStream(); try { ObjectOutputStream oos = new ObjectOutputStream(bos); oos.writeObject(obj); oos.flush(); oos.close(); bos.close(); bytes = bos.toByteArray(); } catch (IOException ex) { System.out.println(ex); } return bytes;

units.rawText: byte[] bytes = null; ByteArrayOutputStream bos = new ByteArrayOutputStream(); try { ObjectOutputStream oos = new ObjectOutputStream(bos); oos.writeObject(obj); oos.flush(); oos.close(); bos.close(); bytes = bos.toByteArray(); } catch (IOException ex) { System.out.println(ex); } return bytes;

node.contents: There was a way to do this with block memory mapping a file (and only store it on purpose). But yet again a file pointer is different.

astNode.text: There was a way to do this with block memory mapping a file (and only store it on purpose). But yet again a file pointer is different.

node.contents: This cannot be done for an in-memory data structure in java.

astNode.text: This cannot be done for an in-memory data structure in java.

node.contents: The jvm specification is deliberately vague about how object references are stored and allocated in order to allow different jvm implementations to make different choices as to how they implement garbage collection, etc.

astNode.text: The jvm specification is deliberately vague about how object references are stored and allocated in order to allow different jvm implementations to make different choices as to how they implement garbage collection, etc.

node.contents: The best you can do (if working in memory) is to emulate an address space with a large byte array, where you are using the index in the array as a pointer.

astNode.text: The best you can do (if working in memory) is to emulate an address space with a large byte array, where you are using the index in the array as a pointer.

node.contents: If working on disk, that is a different story as disk based storage is accessible by offset and pointers make sense but your in-memory data structure becomes irrelevant

astNode.text: If working on disk, that is a different story as disk based storage is accessible by offset and pointers make sense but your in-memory data structure becomes irrelevant

node.contents: @AnupamGupta I am not sure what you are trying to do. References cannot be stored. When you assign reference `A` to reference `B` like `B = A;`, this will make `B` pointing to the object that `A` is pointing to! See [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/12444216/597657), and [this one](http://stackoverflow.com/a/9404727/597657) for more information.

astNode.text: @AnupamGupta I am not sure what you are trying to do. References cannot be stored. When you assign reference `A` to reference `B` like `B = A;`, this will make `B` pointing to the object that `A` is pointing to! See [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/12444216/597657), and [this one](http://stackoverflow.com/a/9404727/597657) for more information.

node.contents: You can serialize any object via ObjectOutputStream (Note that you must add implements Serializable to your class Block). For example:
